title.abbrev: SMTP IPv6 to IPv4 fall back

front.title: SMTP IPv6 to IPv4 fall back

abstract.t: This document describes how some MTA software can be made to fall back to IPv4 when a message is refused over IPv6

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Under RFC 5321, the process of target host selection is described. SMTP clients in well know MTA software will retry to send a message at a different MX RR or IP Address if the message is temporarly rejected. This document describes under which circumstances these MTAs can be made to retry over IPv4. This behavior could be useful for instance in enforcing higher requirements for SMTP over IPv6 than what exists on IPv4 while not simply rejecting outright the message.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Moving from IP reputation to domain based reputation
section.t: IPv6 brings more IP addresses, building an IP based reputation system using IPv6 addresses could be difficult to achieve. Moving from an IP based reputation systems to a domain based reputation system could be easier. However it requires that all SMTP servers participate. With IPv6 there is a chance to mandate SPF (RFC 6652) or DKIM (RFC 6376) for messages sent over IPv6 and if not to be retried over IPv4.

section.title: MX RR configuration
section.t: When a message is temporarly refused the strategy for the SMTP client is to sometimes retry immediately to a different MX

When the MX RR points to a dual stacked machine, some MTA software will not pick up all the A or AAAA RR but the RR which is preferred as per the IP stack, therefore it is important to not have any MX RR point to dual stacked machines.

figure.preamble: For instance the following configuration is desired:
figure.artwork: example.org. IN MX 10 mx1.example.org. IN MX 10 mx1-6.example.org. mx1.example.org. IN A 192.0.2.1 mx1-6.example.org. IN AAAA 2001:db8:ffff::1

section.t: In this configuration, the SMTP clients see two MXes of same priority, and will automatically pick one or the other and try the other one if the message is properly temp failed.

section.title: Rejecting messages for immediate retry on IPv4
section.t: SMTP clients only interpret SMTP status codes, but the use of SMTP enhanced status codes can be used to better monitor and act on the reason of the temporary failure.
The SMTP client SHOULD be presented with a temporary failure code 4xx at the end of DATA for the message to be retried.
If the SMTP client is presented with a permanent failure code 5xx during connection, some MTA software will declare the message non deliverable, instead of retrying it on a different MX.
At connection time if the SMTP server reject using the code 451 and disconnect, the SMTP client will retry the message immediately on a different MX.
At the end of data if the SMTP server reject using the code 421 and disconnect, the SMTP client will retry the message immediately on a different MX.

For instance, at the end of DATA, if the message was sent over IPv6, the SMTP server can evalute if the message passes SPF or DKIM and reject the message using 421 if none pass. If one pass, then we have an authenticated domain where we can apply domain reputation rules. The IPv6 of the SMTP client can be noted, and futher connections over IPv6 can be temporary rejected using 451 status code for a certain time period as to minimize resources to evaluate each message after the end of DATA. If a message coming from a defined IPv6 address does not have SPF or DKIM, it is unlikely that this state would quickly change for the next message coming from this IP.
This behavior has been observed for well known opensource MTAs.

For proprietary mail systems or large mailbox providers, they all do a form of domain authentication, either SPF or DKIM, so the above may not apply to them. Not all are yet enabled to send email over IPv6.

figure.preamble: Here is an example of an initial message sent over IPv6. The SMTP client then retries immediately on the next MX record, here an IPv4 address.
figure.artwork: S: 220 foo.com Simple Mail Transfer Service Ready C: EHLO bar.com S: 250-foo.com greets bar.com over IPv6 S: 250-8BITMIME S: 250-SIZE S: 250-DSN S: 250 HELP C: MAIL FROM:<Smith@bar.com> S: 250 OK C: RCPT TO:<Jones@foo.com> S: 250 OK C: RCPT TO:<Green@foo.com> S: 550 No such user here C: RCPT TO:<Brown@foo.com> S: 250 OK C: DATA S: 354 Start mail input; end with <CRLF>.<CRLF> C: Blah blah blah... C: ...etc. etc. etc. C: . S: 421 4.4.8 message with no SPF or DKIM and over IPv6 C: QUIT S: 221 foo.com Service closing transmission channel

figure.preamble: In this case the SMTP client has been previously temporary rejected but re-attempt to send a new message over IPv6.
figure.artwork: S: 451 4.4.8 Come back on IPv4 as I told you before

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Sender-SMTP may not fall back to IPv4 when requested and keep retrying over and over on IPv6. MTA administrators SHOULD monitor for such servers. MTA Administrators MAY Whitelist them to accept messages over IPv6 or take appropriate action.
